elements.content: Cocrystals and isomers, two well-known unique concepts in supramolecular chemistry, are rarely put together until now. For the first time, we report three unprecedented and interesting cocrystals of twin isomers of coordination polymers (CPs) in situ formed by typical Keggin anions and Cu­(II)–4,4′-bis­(hydroxymethyl)-2,2′-bipyridine (Cu­(II)–H2L) complex moieties. In cocrystals 1–3, the Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties are quadrisupported on Keggin-type anions through W­(Mo)–Ot–Cu–Ot–W­(Mo) (Ot is the terminal O atom) links in the crystal to form two twin ionic/neutral CPs with a fixed chemical stoichiometry. Cocrystals 1–2 contain ionic isomers as {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[P1W12O40]} n n+/{[Cu2­(HL)­(H2O)2]2[P2W12O40]} n n– for 1 and {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[P1Mo12O40]} n n+/{[Cu2­(HL)­(H2O)2]2[P2Mo12O40]} n n– for 2. Cocrystal 3 contains neutral isomers as {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[Si1W12O40]} n and {[Cu2­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[Si2W12O40]} n . Cooperation of conformation and hydrogen bond network isomerism of Cu­(II)–H2L fragments and tetracoordinated mode isomerism of Keggin anion is perfectly embodied in twin isomers. Moreover, based on hydrogen-bonding interactions, twin isomers are alternately arranged in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio to give a cocrystal. Complicated accumulation of three types of hydrogen-bonding assemblies in the same crystal may be the reason that they give conductivity values over 10–4 S·cm–1 at 100 °C under 98% relative humidity.

Cocrystals 1-2 contain ionic isomers as {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[P1W12O40]} n   n+/{[Cu2(HL)(H2O)2]2[P2W12O40]} n   n- for 1 and {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[P1Mo12O40]} n   n+/{[Cu2(HL)(H2O)2]2[P2Mo12O40]} n   n- for 2. Cocrystal 3 contains neutral isomers as {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[Si1W12O40]} n  and {[Cu2(H2L)(H2O)2]2[Si2W12O40]} n . elements.content: Supramolecular synthesis is the self-assembly of preselected molecular components. Isomers and cocrystals are two well-known unique concepts in supramolecular chemistry. The construction of supramolecular isomers is the controlled assembly and crystallization of preselected molecular components on the basis of an unfixed or a fixed chemical stoichiometry. Because many factors can influence the composition of supramolecular isomers, the construction of supramolecular isomers is a significant task in understanding supramolecular isomerism and crystal growth. The simple crystallization system results in the wide occurrence of supramolecular isomerism for molecular crystals, especially for organic molecules. In contrast with molecular crystals, very intricate multicomponent crystallization systems result in less observable isomers for coordination polymers (CPs), although multicomponent CPs might provide possibilities for cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism being embodied in isomers. To date, there are no reports on cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism in isomers for CPs. Therefore, studying supramolecular isomerism and cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism are two of the important steps toward crystal engineering of CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Supramolecular synthesis is the self-assembly of preselected molecular components. Isomers and cocrystals are two well-known unique concepts in supramolecular chemistry. The construction of supramolecular isomers is the controlled assembly and crystallization of preselected molecular components on the basis of an unfixed or a fixed chemical stoichiometry. Because many factors can influence the composition of supramolecular isomers, the construction of supramolecular isomers is a significant task in understanding supramolecular isomerism and crystal growth. The simple crystallization system results in the wide occurrence of supramolecular isomerism for molecular crystals, especially for organic molecules. In contrast with molecular crystals, very intricate multicomponent crystallization systems result in less observable isomers for coordination polymers (CPs), although multicomponent CPs might provide possibilities for cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism being embodied in isomers. To date, there are no reports on cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism in isomers for CPs. Therefore, studying supramolecular isomerism and cooperativeness of several types of supramolecular isomerism are two of the important steps toward crystal engineering of CPs.

elements.content: As a versatile approach to generating new crystalline materials, cocrystallization of two or more different molecular and/or ionic species generally in a stoichiometric ratio has substantial significance for supramolecular assemblies. It is well-known that cocrystallization could modify physical properties of the active pharmaceutical ingredient in the pharmaceutical industry. It also has broader applications in the design of systems with favorable proton-transfer properties. Cocrystallization process frequently uses highly directional hydrogen bonding as the interaction and thus can often produce predictable supramolecular units. However, the combining of isomers and cocrystals for the preparation of new crystalline materials has been unexplored. Generally speaking, as two distinct molecular species, supramolecular isomers often show polymorphism. There is little knowledge about cocrystallization of supramolecular isomers, especially for twin supramolecular isomers. Therefore, to find suitable molecular building blocks and synthesis condition for cocrystallization of in situ assembled twin supramolecular isomers for CPs with a fixed chemical stoichiometry becomes very necessary and interesting.

elements.content: Keggin-polyoxometalates (POMs) and metal–4,4′-bis­(hydroxymethyl)-2,2′-bipyridine (H2L) complex moieties are important inorganic and metal–organic molecular building units for the construction of supramolecular compounds. As two preselected molecular components, the functionalization of Keggin anion with metal–H2L complex moieties to construct CPs may be one useful strategy for studying cocrystallization of twin supramolecular isomers with a fixed chemical stoichiometry. Cocrystals of isomers for Keggin-based CPs may also be one type of new crystalline materials with favorable proton conductivity. As a substituted 2,2-bipyridine (bpy) ligand, H2L is also basically inclined to form single-metal–organic clusters with the chelated coordination mode, resulting in cis conformation. The difference is that in H2L, the flexibility and conformational freedom of the CH2OH groups allow the C–O bonds to rotate freely to satisfy the requirement of hydrogen-bond building. It is predictable that metal–H2L fragments could provide conformation and hydrogen-bonding network isomerism in CPs. Keggin-POM has the relatively large volume and shows the relatively weak coordination ability compared with the organic ligands. Usually, the organic ligand with the smaller steric hindrance and POM anion with the larger volume favor the POM anion acting as a high-connected linkage in the CPs. As reported, a mixed-metal reduced tetracapped pseudo-Keggin [PMoVI 6MoV 2VIV 8O44]5– unit and Co-bpy complex moieties give a tetrasupporting polyoxocation. The larger steric hindrance of H2L than that of bpy ligand make the typical Keggin anion potentially support by four metal–H2L fragments, that is, Keggin-POM as polydentate oxygen donor ligand has the potential to provide tetracoordinated mode isomerism of Keggin anion in CPs.
elements.clean_text: Keggin-polyoxometalates (POMs) and metal-4,4'-bis(hydroxymethyl)-2,2'-bipyridine (H2L) complex moieties are important inorganic and metal-organic molecular building units for the construction of supramolecular compounds. As two preselected molecular components, the functionalization of Keggin anion with metal-H2L complex moieties to construct CPs may be one useful strategy for studying cocrystallization of twin supramolecular isomers with a fixed chemical stoichiometry. Cocrystals of isomers for Keggin-based CPs may also be one type of new crystalline materials with favorable proton conductivity. As a substituted 2,2-bipyridine (bpy) ligand, H2L is also basically inclined to form single-metal-organic clusters with the chelated coordination mode, resulting in cis conformation. The difference is that in H2L, the flexibility and conformational freedom of the CH2OH groups allow the C-O bonds to rotate freely to satisfy the requirement of hydrogen-bond building. It is predictable that metal-H2L fragments could provide conformation and hydrogen-bonding network isomerism in CPs. Keggin-POM has the relatively large volume and shows the relatively weak coordination ability compared with the organic ligands. Usually, the organic ligand with the smaller steric hindrance and POM anion with the larger volume favor the POM anion acting as a high-connected linkage in the CPs. As reported, a mixed-metal reduced tetracapped pseudo-Keggin [PMoVI 6MoV 2VIV 8O44]5- unit and Co-bpy complex moieties give a tetrasupporting polyoxocation. The larger steric hindrance of H2L than that of bpy ligand make the typical Keggin anion potentially support by four metal-H2L fragments, that is, Keggin-POM as polydentate oxygen donor ligand has the potential to provide tetracoordinated mode isomerism of Keggin anion in CPs.

elements.content: In a word, Keggin-POMs and metal–H2L complex moieties, respectively, acting as suitable inorganic and metal–organic building units are selected for the syntheses of cocrystals of multi-isomerism-integrated isomers of CPs. Their combination may open a new direction for proton-conductive cocrystallization materials of supramolecular isomers. Very fortunately, based on three typical Keggin anions ([PW12O40]3–, [PMo12O40]3– and [SiW12O40]4–), and Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties, three cocrystals (1–3) of multi-isomerism-integrated twin CP isomers are obtained for the first time. As predicted, cooperation of conformation and hydrogen bond network isomerism of Cu­(II)–H2L fragments and tetracoordinated mode isomerism of Keggin anion are perfectly embodied in twin isomers. Thus, three cocrystals (1–3) would provide models to test the dependence of the proton mobility in these cocrystals with complicated hydrogen-bonding networks on the temperature and relative humidity (RH). The similar structural properties result in their similar proton conductivities. They give conductivity values over 10–4 S·cm–1 at 100 °C under 98% RH. Their syntheses, crystal structures, and proton conductivities as a function of temperature and RH are reported in this article.
elements.clean_text: In a word, Keggin-POMs and metal-H2L complex moieties, respectively, acting as suitable inorganic and metal-organic building units are selected for the syntheses of cocrystals of multi-isomerism-integrated isomers of CPs. Their combination may open a new direction for proton-conductive cocrystallization materials of supramolecular isomers. Very fortunately, based on three typical Keggin anions ([PW12O40]3-, [PMo12O40]3- and [SiW12O40]4-), and Cu(II)-H2L complex moieties, three cocrystals (1-3) of multi-isomerism-integrated twin CP isomers are obtained for the first time. As predicted, cooperation of conformation and hydrogen bond network isomerism of Cu(II)-H2L fragments and tetracoordinated mode isomerism of Keggin anion are perfectly embodied in twin isomers. Thus, three cocrystals (1-3) would provide models to test the dependence of the proton mobility in these cocrystals with complicated hydrogen-bonding networks on the temperature and relative humidity (RH). The similar structural properties result in their similar proton conductivities. They give conductivity values over 10-4 S⋅cm-1 at 100 °C under 98% RH. Their syntheses, crystal structures, and proton conductivities as a function of temperature and RH are reported in this article.

elements.content: The title complexes were synthesized using organic solvents and materials of reagent grade. CuHPMo12O40·nH2O, CuHPW12O40·nH2O, and Cu2SiW12O40·nH2O were prepared according to a literature method. 4,4′-Bis­(hydroxymethyl)-2,2′-bipyridine (H2L) was obtained from Zhengzhou Alfachem Co. Ltd.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The title complexes were synthesized using organic solvents and materials of reagent grade. CuHPMo12O40⋅nH2O, CuHPW12O40⋅nH2O, and Cu2SiW12O40⋅nH2O were prepared according to a literature method. 4,4'-Bis(hydroxymethyl)-2,2'-bipyridine (H2L) was obtained from Zhengzhou Alfachem Co. Ltd.

elements.content: The copper heteropolyacid salt (CuHPW12O40·nH2O) (90.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CuCl2·6H2O (5.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) were dissolved in a 4 mL water, which was put in the bottom of the test tube. Next, a solution (9 mL) of methanol/acetonitrile/water (1:1:1, v/v/v) was as a buffer layer. Then, a methanol solution (6 mL) of H2L (6.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) and imidazole (3.9 mg, 0.03 mmol) was carefully layered over the buffer layer. Finally, the test tube containing the solution is stoppered and laid aside at room temperature. Light-blue crystals were formed after 4–5 weeks and were collected and dried in air after quickly being washed with water. Yield: 66.6 mg, 74% based on POMs. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C52H86Cu4N8O104P2W24 (7215.78): C, 8.65; H, 1.20; N, 1.55. Found: C, 8.59; H, 1.16; N, 1.48. IR (KBr) ν, cm–1: 804ν­(W–Oc), 889ν­(W–Ob), 980ν­(W–Ot), 1072ν­(P–Oa) (characteristic vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with the Keggin structure); 3417, 3128, 1619, 1399 (vibrations resulting from the H2L ligand).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

{[Cu(H2L)(H2O)2]2[PW12O40]}{[Cu(HL)(H2O)2]2[PW12O40]}⋅4CH3OH⋅4H2O (1)

The copper heteropolyacid salt (CuHPW12O40⋅nH2O) (90.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CuCl2⋅6H2O (5.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) were dissolved in a 4 mL water, which was put in the bottom of the test tube. Next, a solution (9 mL) of methanol/acetonitrile/water (1:1:1, v/v/v) was as a buffer layer. Then, a methanol solution (6 mL) of H2L (6.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) and imidazole (3.9 mg, 0.03 mmol) was carefully layered over the buffer layer. Finally, the test tube containing the solution is stoppered and laid aside at room temperature. Light-blue crystals were formed after 4-5 weeks and were collected and dried in air after quickly being washed with water. Yield: 66.6 mg, 74% based on POMs. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C52H86Cu4N8O104P2W24 (7215.78): C, 8.65; H, 1.20; N, 1.55. Found: C, 8.59; H, 1.16; N, 1.48. IR (KBr) ν, cm-1: 804ν(W-Oc), 889ν(W-Ob), 980ν(W-Ot), 1072ν(P-Oa) (characteristic vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with the Keggin structure); 3417, 3128, 1619, 1399 (vibrations resulting from the H2L ligand).

elements.content: A PerkinElmer 240C analyzer was used for elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out on a Bruker D8 Avance Instrument (Cu Kα radiation and a fixed power source of 40 kv, 40 mA). A VECTOR 22 Bruker spectrophotometer was used for IR spectra with KBr pellets from 400 to 4000 cm–1 at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a PerkinElmer thermal analyzer. Water absorption experiments were performed on an AQUALAB VSA. The PXRD experiments confirmed the phase purity of bulk materials. The powdered crystalline samples are used for the electrical conductivity study. They are compressed to pellets under a pressure of 12–14 MPa (about 1.0 mm in thickness and 12.0 mm in diameter). The sample was placed in a temperature–humidity-controlled chamber (GT-TH-64Z, Dongwan Gaotian Corp.). The ac frequencies are over the frequency range from 105 to 10 Hz with a 5 mV signal amplitude. A CHI660D (Shanghai Chenhua) electrochemical impedance analyzer and a conventional three-electrode method were used for the ac impedance spectroscopy measurement with copper electrodes. The resistances were obtained from the extrapolation to the real axis. On the basis of σ = (1/R) × (h/S) (where R is the resistance, h is the thickness, and S is the area of the tablet), the conductivities of solid samples of three cocrystals (1–3) were calculated.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

A PerkinElmer 240C analyzer was used for elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out on a Bruker D8 Avance Instrument (Cu Kα radiation and a fixed power source of 40 kv, 40 mA). A VECTOR 22 Bruker spectrophotometer was used for IR spectra with KBr pellets from 400 to 4000 cm-1 at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a PerkinElmer thermal analyzer. Water absorption experiments were performed on an AQUALAB VSA. The PXRD experiments confirmed the phase purity of bulk materials. The powdered crystalline samples are used for the electrical conductivity study. They are compressed to pellets under a pressure of 12-14 MPa (about 1.0 mm in thickness and 12.0 mm in diameter). The sample was placed in a temperature-humidity-controlled chamber (GT-TH-64Z, Dongwan Gaotian Corp.). The ac frequencies are over the frequency range from 105 to 10 Hz with a 5 mV signal amplitude. A CHI660D (Shanghai Chenhua) electrochemical impedance analyzer and a conventional three-electrode method were used for the ac impedance spectroscopy measurement with copper electrodes. The resistances were obtained from the extrapolation to the real axis. On the basis of σ = (1/R) × (h/S) (where R is the resistance, h is the thickness, and S is the area of the tablet), the conductivities of solid samples of three cocrystals (1-3) were calculated.

elements.content: Diffraction data for suitable single crystals of three cocrystals (1–3) were collected on Bruker Apex charge-coupled device area detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The programs SAINT and SADABS were used for processing data and absorption correction based on symmetry equivalent reflections, respectively. By full-matrix least-squares techniques, the structures of three cocrystals were solved by direct method using the SHELX97 program and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2014 package. Nonhydrogen atoms, except for some disordered oxygen atoms from the polyanion and C, N, O atoms of solvent molecules, were refined anisotropically. Organic molecule hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Coordinated water hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of solvent water were not treated.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analyses

Diffraction data for suitable single crystals of three cocrystals (1-3) were collected on Bruker Apex charge-coupled device area detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The programs SAINT and SADABS were used for processing data and absorption correction based on symmetry equivalent reflections, respectively. By full-matrix least-squares techniques, the structures of three cocrystals were solved by direct method using the SHELX97 program and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2014 package. Nonhydrogen atoms, except for some disordered oxygen atoms from the polyanion and C, N, O atoms of solvent molecules, were refined anisotropically. Organic molecule hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. Coordinated water hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of solvent water were not treated.

elements.content: 1–3 are very complicated systems. It is unavoidable that there appears to be close contacts among some atoms; there is a larger than usual U(eq) range for the specified element type as O in the nonsolvent/anion part of the structures of 1–3, some atoms have large ADP max/min ratio (O27 4.1, O29 4.5, C16 4.9 for 1 and C19 4.7, O4W 4.1 for 3), and some atoms (O18, O32, and O44) in 3 show high “MainMol” U eq as compared to neighbors. The use of a DAMP instruction (2000.0 for 1, 1500.0 for 2, and 1100.0 for 3) in the final refinement job of 1–3 is to improve the bond precision on C–C bonds. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results are summarized in . Selected hydrogen bond lengths are shown in . Selected Cu­(II) coordination bond lengths (Å) in 1–3 and Cu­(II) coordination sphere in 1 are shown in . Representative atom–atom distances and bond angles based on Keggin anions in 1–3 are shown in Table S1. Mean deviation from plane and dihedral angle of H2L ligands in 1–3 are shown in Table S2.

Selected Cu­(II) Coordination Bond Lengths (Å) in <bold>1–3</bold> and Cu­(II) Coordination Sphere in <bold>1</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref>

Symmetric transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: #1: −x + 3, −y, and −z + 1; #2: −x + 2, −y, and −z + 1; #3: −x, −y, and −z + 2; and #4: −x + 1, −y, and −z + 1.

The +VI oxidation state of W/Mo atoms and the +II oxidation state of Cu atoms in 1–3 are confirmed by bond valence sum (BVS) calculations. To locate the possible positions of protons on H2L, BVS calculations of all hydroxy oxygen atoms in 1–3 have been performed (BVS values in 1: 0.90 for O45, 0.91 for O46, 1.54 for O47, and 0.96 for O48; BVS values in 2: 0.96 for O45, 0.93 for O46, 1.24 for O47, and 1.08 for O48; BVS values in 3: 1.09 for O45, 0.93 for O46, 1.02 for O47, and 0.96 for O48). In 1–2, the BVS values of O45, O46, and O48 atoms are significantly lower than that of O47 atom, indicative of O45, O46, and O48 centers being the possible binding sites of protons and the proton of O47 center being lost for charge balance. In 3, the BVS values of O45, O46, O47, and O48 atoms are similar, indicative of four oxygen atoms being the possible binding sites of protons.

elements.content: In the Keggin anions in 1–3, the central P/Si atom is surrounded by a cube of eight oxygen atoms with each oxygen site being half-occupied and crystallographically disordered. Each of the central oxygen atoms links three W/Mo atoms. This case can be found in many compounds based on Keggin-POMs.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analyses at room temperature revealed that cocrystals 1–3 were crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c and have similar structural features. Cocrystal 1 contains two ionic CP isomers as {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[P1W12O40]} n n+ and {[Cu2­(HL)­(H2O)2]2[P2W12O40]} n n– ([Cu1L-P1W] n n+ and [Cu2L-P2W] n n–) (). Cocrystal 2 contains two ionic CP isomers as {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[P1Mo12O40]} n n+ and {[Cu2­(HL)­(H2O)2]2[P2Mo12O40]} n n– ([Cu1L-P1Mo] n n+ and [Cu2L-P2Mo] n n–) (). Cocrystal 3 contains two neutral CP isomers as {[Cu1­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[Si1W12O40]} n and {[Cu2­(H2L)­(H2O)2]2[Si2W12O40]} n ([Cu1L-Si1W] n and [Cu2L-Si2W] n ) (). First, each of the H2L ligands in 1–3 acts as a bidentate nitrogen donor ligand to form a single-metal–organic cluster, Cu­(II)–H2L ([Cu1L]2+ and [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+) (a,c and a,c). The binding angle of the 2,2′-substitution of the N atoms makes the H2L ligand give the most commonly seen coordination mode, the chelating fashion, in its N,N cis conformation. The Cu center in Cu­(II)–H2L fragment is involved in the CuN2O4 core in an octahedral environment. The Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties show two types of conformation isomerism of groups [Cu1L]2+ and [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+ (c and c). In addition, the Keggin anions provide two types of tetracoordinated mode isomerism [P1W]3–/[P1Mo]3–/[Si1W]4– and [P2W]3–/[P2Mo]3–/[Si2W]4– (b and b). Second, following the principle of space matching, one [P1W]3–/[P1Mo]3–/[Si1W]4– anion combines with four [Cu1L]2+ clusters to form the [Cu1L-P1W]+/[Cu1L-P1Mo]+/[Cu1L-Si1W] Keggin cluster, whereas one [P2W]3–/[P2Mo]3–/[Si2W]4– anion unites four [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+ clusters to give the [Cu2L-P2W]−/[Cu2L-P2Mo]−/[Cu2L-Si2W] Keggin cluster, realizing the cooperation of coordination-conformation modes in a unit cell. As a result, there are two twin ionic/neutral quadridecorated Keggin clusters in the molecular structural unit (a and a, Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information). Finally, two types of Keggin clusters covalently assemble into two CP isomers in a unit cell (a,b). Moreover, Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties construct two types of hydrogen-bonding double/single helix chains with opposite chirality in two CPs (e and d). In a word, 1–3 are crystalline single-phase materials composed of multi-isomerism-integrated twin ionic/neutral CP isomers in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio (c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

X-ray diffraction analyses at room temperature revealed that cocrystals 1-3 were crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c and have similar structural features. Cocrystal 1 contains two ionic CP isomers as {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[P1W12O40]} n   n+ and {[Cu2(HL)(H2O)2]2[P2W12O40]} n   n- ([Cu1L-P1W] n   n+ and [Cu2L-P2W] n   n-) (). Cocrystal 2 contains two ionic CP isomers as {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[P1Mo12O40]} n   n+ and {[Cu2(HL)(H2O)2]2[P2Mo12O40]} n   n- ([Cu1L-P1Mo] n   n+ and [Cu2L-P2Mo] n   n-) (). Cocrystal 3 contains two neutral CP isomers as {[Cu1(H2L)(H2O)2]2[Si1W12O40]} n  and {[Cu2(H2L)(H2O)2]2[Si2W12O40]} n  ([Cu1L-Si1W] n  and [Cu2L-Si2W] n ) (). First, each of the H2L ligands in 1-3 acts as a bidentate nitrogen donor ligand to form a single-metal-organic cluster, Cu(II)-H2L ([Cu1L]2+ and [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+) (a,c and a,c). The binding angle of the 2,2'-substitution of the N atoms makes the H2L ligand give the most commonly seen coordination mode, the chelating fashion, in its N,N cis conformation. The Cu center in Cu(II)-H2L fragment is involved in the CuN2O4 core in an octahedral environment. The Cu(II)-H2L complex moieties show two types of conformation isomerism of groups [Cu1L]2+ and [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+ (c and c). In addition, the Keggin anions provide two types of tetracoordinated mode isomerism [P1W]3-/[P1Mo]3-/[Si1W]4- and [P2W]3-/[P2Mo]3-/[Si2W]4- (b and b). Second, following the principle of space matching, one [P1W]3-/[P1Mo]3-/[Si1W]4- anion combines with four [Cu1L]2+ clusters to form the [Cu1L-P1W]+/[Cu1L-P1Mo]+/[Cu1L-Si1W] Keggin cluster, whereas one [P2W]3-/[P2Mo]3-/[Si2W]4- anion unites four [Cu2L]+/[Cu2L]2+ clusters to give the [Cu2L-P2W]-/[Cu2L-P2Mo]-/[Cu2L-Si2W] Keggin cluster, realizing the cooperation of coordination-conformation modes in a unit cell. As a result, there are two twin ionic/neutral quadridecorated Keggin clusters in the molecular structural unit (a and a, Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information). Finally, two types of Keggin clusters covalently assemble into two CP isomers in a unit cell (a,b). Moreover, Cu(II)-H2L complex moieties construct two types of hydrogen-bonding double/single helix chains with opposite chirality in two CPs (e and d). In a word, 1-3 are crystalline single-phase materials composed of multi-isomerism-integrated twin ionic/neutral CP isomers in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio (c).

elements.content: Cocrystal of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers. (a) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu1L-P1W] n n+/[Cu1L-[P1Mo] n n+/[Cu1L-Si1W] n in 1–3. (b) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu2L-P2W] n n–/[Cu2L-P2Mo] n n–/[Cu2L-Si2W] n in 1–3. (c) Cocrystallization of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers through hydrogen bonds in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio.

elements.content: Cocrystal 1 is used as a representative for their structural description in detail. As shown in , the molecular structural unit of 1 includes two twin ionic quadridecorated Keggin-type clusters, [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]−. Although the proton of O47 center being lost for charge balance makes [Cu2L-P2W]− and [Cu1L-P1W]+ show subtle element difference, they should belong to twin supramolecular isomers with a fixed chemical stoichiometry.
elements.clean_text: Cocrystal 1 is used as a representative for their structural description in detail. As shown in , the molecular structural unit of 1 includes two twin ionic quadridecorated Keggin-type clusters, [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]-. Although the proton of O47 center being lost for charge balance makes [Cu2L-P2W]- and [Cu1L-P1W]+ show subtle element difference, they should belong to twin supramolecular isomers with a fixed chemical stoichiometry.

elements.content: In the [Cu1L-P1W]+ cation, [P1W]3– acts as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand (O5, O5#3, O10, and O10#3) to coordinate with four Cu1­(II) ions belonging to four [Cu1L]2+ (a,b). O5 and O10, two Ot atoms, are from two WO6 octahedrons (W1 and W2), and they also belong to two separate W3O10 clusters. There are no bridge oxygen atoms (Ob) between the two W3O10 clusters. The distances of W1···W2 and W1#3···W2 are, respectively, 4.927(9) and 5.105(10) Å, which are nearly equal. The W1···P1···W2 angle is 87.97°, which is close to 90.0°. Thus, the W1···W2···W1#3···W2#3 quadrangle is nearly square (b). The distances of Cu1–O5 and Cu1–O10 are, respectively, 2.734(9) and 2.312(11) Å. The large difference of two Cu1–O bonds results in the double-deck arrangement of [Cu1L]2+ fragments around the global [P1W]3– anion.
elements.clean_text: In the [Cu1L-P1W]+ cation, [P1W]3- acts as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand (O5, O5#3, O10, and O10#3) to coordinate with four Cu1(II) ions belonging to four [Cu1L]2+ (a,b). O5 and O10, two Ot atoms, are from two WO6 octahedrons (W1 and W2), and they also belong to two separate W3O10 clusters. There are no bridge oxygen atoms (Ob) between the two W3O10 clusters. The distances of W1⋅⋅⋅W2 and W1#3⋅⋅⋅W2 are, respectively, 4.927(9) and 5.105(10) Å, which are nearly equal. The W1⋅⋅⋅P1⋅⋅⋅W2 angle is 87.97°, which is close to 90.0°. Thus, the W1⋅⋅⋅W2⋅⋅⋅W1#3⋅⋅⋅W2#3 quadrangle is nearly square (b). The distances of Cu1-O5 and Cu1-O10 are, respectively, 2.734(9) and 2.312(11) Å. The large difference of two Cu1-O bonds results in the double-deck arrangement of [Cu1L]2+ fragments around the global [P1W]3- anion.

elements.content: In the [Cu2L-P2W]− anion, [P2W]3– anion also acts as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand (O27, O27#8, O33, and O33#8) to coordinate with four Cu2­(II) ions belonging to four [Cu2­(HL)­(H2O)]+ ([Cu2L]+) (a,b). O27 and O33, two Ot atoms, are from two WO6 octahedrons (W7 and W9), and they also belong to two separate W3O10 clusters. There is one Ob center between the two W3O10 clusters. The distances of W7···W9 and W7#8···W9 are 3.540(9) and 6.152(8) Å, respectively. The W7···P2···W9 angle is 59.84°, which is far away from 90°. As a result, the W7···W9···W7#8···W9#8 quadrangle is rectangular (b). The distances of Cu1–O27 and Cu2–O33 are, respectively, 2.483(10) and 2.470(11) Å, which are nearly equal. The small difference of two Cu2–O bonds results in the single-deck arrangement of [Cu2L]2+ fragments around the global [P2W]3– anion. In terms of [PW]3– anion acting as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand to coordinate with four [CuL] units, the short distance of W7···W9 (3.540 Å) in [P2W]3– may result in a larger steric hindrance than the long distance of W1···W2 (4.927 Å) in the [P1W]3–.
elements.clean_text: In the [Cu2L-P2W]- anion, [P2W]3- anion also acts as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand (O27, O27#8, O33, and O33#8) to coordinate with four Cu2(II) ions belonging to four [Cu2(HL)(H2O)]+ ([Cu2L]+) (a,b). O27 and O33, two Ot atoms, are from two WO6 octahedrons (W7 and W9), and they also belong to two separate W3O10 clusters. There is one Ob center between the two W3O10 clusters. The distances of W7⋅⋅⋅W9 and W7#8⋅⋅⋅W9 are 3.540(9) and 6.152(8) Å, respectively. The W7⋅⋅⋅P2⋅⋅⋅W9 angle is 59.84°, which is far away from 90°. As a result, the W7⋅⋅⋅W9⋅⋅⋅W7#8⋅⋅⋅W9#8 quadrangle is rectangular (b). The distances of Cu1-O27 and Cu2-O33 are, respectively, 2.483(10) and 2.470(11) Å, which are nearly equal. The small difference of two Cu2-O bonds results in the single-deck arrangement of [Cu2L]2+ fragments around the global [P2W]3- anion. In terms of [PW]3- anion acting as a quadridentate oxygen donor ligand to coordinate with four [CuL] units, the short distance of W7⋅⋅⋅W9 (3.540 Å) in [P2W]3- may result in a larger steric hindrance than the long distance of W1⋅⋅⋅W2 (4.927 Å) in the [P1W]3-.

elements.content: Compared with rigid global Keggin anions, Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties show flexibility and provide diverse conformation modes. In [Cu1L]2+, the dihedral angle of N 1-py (N 1-pyridine) and N 2-py is 7.2°. In [Cu2L]+, the dihedral angle of N 3-py and N 4-py is 5.9°. Therefore, the bpy part of the H2L ligand shows an obvious deviation from planarity. In addition, based on the plane which divides two pyridyl rings of the H2L ligand, the OH groups may be directed toward or away from the plane, respectively, giving endo or exo conformation. In the [Cu1L]2+, two CH2OH groups are in the exo,exo conformation. The O···O distance of CH2OH groups, O45···O46, is 10.013 Å, which is close to the mean diameter of [PW]3– of 10.48 Å (based on four coordination Ot atoms) (c). However, in the [Cu2L]+, two CH2OH groups are in the endo,exo conformation. Notably, the O···O distance, O47···O48, is 8.288 Å, which is away from the mean diameter of [PW]3– of 10.48 Å (c). In this point, the steric hindrance of H2L ligand in [Cu1L]2+ is larger than that in [Cu2L]+.

elements.content: Following the principle of space matching, [P1W]3– combines with [Cu1L]2+ to form the [Cu1L-P1W]+ isomer, whereas [P2W]3– unites [Cu2L]+ to give the [Cu2L-P2W]− isomer, realizing the cooperation of coordination-conformation modes in a unit cell. Further, the structure of 1 constructed from [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]− isomers exhibits two twin ionic layers with alternating cations and anions through W–Ot–Cu–Ot–W (Ot is the terminal O atom) links in the crystal. Each [Cu1L]2+/[Cu2L]+ cation is covalently bonded to two adjacent [PW12]3– anions via one copper atom. Each typical [PW]3– anion is connected with four [Cu1L]2+/[Cu2L]+ cations via four Ot atoms. Therefore, based on the infinite covalent assembly, two twin [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]− ions, respectively, form two twin isomers of CPs, [Cu1L-P1W] n n+ and [Cu2L-P2W] n n–, with two-dimensional (2D) sheet structures in a unit cell (a,b). In other words, two twin isomers of CPs give a cocrystal. As far as we know, in situ cocrystallization of twin isomers of CPs has never been met before in solid-state material chemistry.

Therefore, based on the infinite covalent assembly, two twin [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]- ions, respectively, form two twin isomers of CPs, [Cu1L-P1W] n   n+ and [Cu2L-P2W] n   n-, with two-dimensional (2D) sheet structures in a unit cell (a,b). In other words, two twin isomers of CPs give a cocrystal. As far as we know, in situ cocrystallization of twin isomers of CPs has never been met before in solid-state material chemistry.

elements.content: More interestingly, as hydrogen bond donors/acceptors, the C–O bonds of the free CH2OH groups could freely rotate to satisfy different requirements of hydrogen-bond building of Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties in twin ionic/neutral quadridecorated Keggin-type clusters. In [Cu1L]2+, the dihedral angle of N 1-py (N 1-pyridine) and O45–C11–C3 triangle plane is 40.0°, and the one of N 2-py and O46–C12–C8 triangle plane is 4.9°. Thus, the N 1,N 2-H2L is considerably noncoplanar with O45–CH2OH group (containing the O45 center) sticking out of and O46–CH2OH approximately retaining in the N 1,N 2-bpy plane (b). Associated with the double-deck arrangement of [Cu1L]2+ fragments around the global [P1W]3– anion, this considerably noncoplanar exo,exo conformation mode contributes to the intricate hydrogen-bonding assemblies of [Cu1L]2+ fragments around global [P1W]3– anions. As illustrated in f, in the [Cu1L-P1W] n n+ isomer, there are hydrogen-bonding interactions between [Cu1L]2+ fragments (O2W···O46#1 2.778, O45···O1W#1 2.843: #1: −x + 3, y – 1/2, and −z + 3/2), as well as between [P1W]3– anions and [Cu1L]2+ fragments (O1W···O6#1 2.844; #1: −x + 3, y + 1/2, and −z + 3/2). Interestingly, based on the cooperation between the coordinated mode of [P1W]3– anion and the conformation mode of N 1,N 2-H2L, [Cu1L]2+ cations formed two types of hydrogen-bonding double-helix chains with opposite chirality along the b axis (e). Each hydrogen-bonding double-helix chain contains such two single-helix chains with opposite chirality as ···O46···O2W–Cu1–N2··· and ···O45···O1W–Cu1–N1··· chains (d). In [Cu2L]+, the dihedral angle of N 3-py and O47–C23–C15 triangle plane is 173.1°, and the one of N 4-py and O48–C24–C20 triangle plane is 165.7°. Therefore, the N 3,N 4-HL is slightly noncoplanar with O47–CH2O– group retaining in and O48–CH2OH group slightly sticking out of the N 3,N 4-bpy plane (c). Combined with the single-deck arrangement of [Cu2L]2+ fragments around the global [P2W]3– anion, this slightly noncoplanar endo,exo conformation mode contributes to the simple hydrogen-bonding assemblies of [Cu2L]+ fragments around [P2W]3– anions. As illustrated in e, in the [Cu2L-P2W] n n– isomer, there are hydrogen-bonding interactions between [Cu2L]+ fragments (O4W···O48#1 2.584; #1: −x + 2, y – 1/2, and −z + 3/2), as well as between [P2W]3– anions and [Cu2L]+ fragments (O3W···O40 2.948). Interestingly, based on the cooperation between the coordinated mode of [P2W]3– anion and the conformation mode of N 3,N 4-HL, [Cu2L]+ cations formed two types of hydrogen-bonding single-helix chains (···O48···O4W–Cu2–N4···) with opposite chirality along the b axis (d). Therefore, in [Cu1L-P1W] n n+ and [Cu2L-P2W] n n– isomers, there are three types of supramolecular isomerism as coordination mode, conformation, and hydrogen bond network isomerism.

elements.content: As illustrated in c, through the hydrogen-bonding interactions between H2L oxygen atoms (O46···O47#1 3.064; #1: x + 1, −y + 1/2, and z + 1/2) as well as among coordinated water molecules, [PW]3– anions and solvent molecules, two twin isomers in 1 cocrystalize according to the ···[Cu1L-P1W] n n+–[Cu2L-P2W] n n–··· pattern to give a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure with 2D hydrophilic layers. In the two adjacent isomer layers, the shortest distance of P1···P2 is 18.08 Å. Cocrystal 1 contains three different types of hydrogen-bonding assemblies as two coordinated hydrogen-bonding ionic/neutral isomer layers and one solvent-molecule hydrogen-bonding layer (f, e, and S3 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In 2, [Cu1L-P1Mo]+ and [Cu2L-P2Mo]− isomers have, respectively, the same structure with the [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]− isomers, except using [PMo]3– anion to replace [PW]3– anion. In 3, [Cu1L-Si1W] and [Cu2L-Si2W] isomers have, respectively, the same structure with the [Cu1L-P1W]+ and [Cu2L-P2W]− isomers, except using [SiW]4– anion to replace [PW]3– anion. For charge balance, [SiW]4– anion gives neutral [Cu1L-Si1W] and [Cu2L-Si2W] isomers with the proton of O47 center being retained. Therefore, neutral [Cu1L-Si1W] and [Cu2L-Si2W] isomers have the exact same element. The successful syntheses of cocrystals of twin supramolecular isomers as 1–3 suggest that accurate prediction of the final superstructures based on suitable molecular building blocks as Keggin-POMs and Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties is possible. Therefore, 1–3 could provide an invaluable opportunity for the study of multi-isomerism cooperation and cocrystallization of supramolecular isomers.

elements.content: The results of the PXRD indicate that the phase purity of the bulk materials of cocrystals 1–3 is in good agreement with the simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). At room temperature and normal pressure, the water vapor adsorption isotherms are tested using three bulk materials. 1–3 show good hydrophilicity and capacity for the inclusion of water molecules between isomer layers at room temperature and normal pressure (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). By gradually adsorbing water, per unit formula of 1–3 could absorb 15.5, 14.3, and 24.3 water molecules, respectively. 1 and 2 show similar water-adsorbing capacity, whereas 3 shows larger water-adsorbing capacity than 1–2. 1–3 have the same isomer layer spacing based on the shortest distance of P1/Si1···P2/Si2 (18.08 Å for 1, 18.09 Å for 2, and 18.07 Å for 3). On the basis of four coordinated terminal oxygen atoms (O5, O10, O27, and O33), the mean diameter of Keggin anion is 10.48 Å for [PW]3–, 10.45 Å for [PMo]3–, and 10.39 Å for [SiW]4– in three cocrystals, respectively. Smaller [SiW]4– anion in 3 makes two isomer layers contact more loosely than those in 1–2, which might make 3 show larger water-adsorbing capacity than 1–2 at room temperature and normal pressure.

On the basis of four coordinated terminal oxygen atoms (O5, O10, O27, and O33), the mean diameter of Keggin anion is 10.48 Å for [PW]3-, 10.45 Å for [PMo]3-, and 10.39 Å for [SiW]4- in three cocrystals, respectively. elements.content: Thermal analyses of three bulk materials in an atmosphere of N2 reveal that the robustness of those networks of cocrystals could retain up to about 300 °C for 1–2 and about 250 °C for 3 (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). In the temperature range of 20–300 °C for 1–2 and 20–250 °C for 3, there is a weight loss of about 3.53% for 1 (4.60% for 2 and 1.90% for 3) corresponding to the loss of all solvent molecules (2.77% for 1, 3.92% for 2, and 2.26% for 3). Above 300 °C for 1–2 and 250 °C for 3, the layer structures of 1–3 begin to decompose because of the loss of coordinated water molecules and H2L ligands, as well as the disrupting of the structural skeletons of the Keggin anions. The weight losses are about 1.22% for 1, 0.93% for 2, and 1.03% for 3 at 100 °C, suggesting that the hydrophilic channels or layers in three complexes could retain some uncoordinated water molecules at 100 °C. The results indicate that three complexes have good water holding in the temperature range of 20–100 °C. The PXRD patterns of the title complexes after heating in an atmosphere of N2 at 700 °C are shown in Figure S5 in the Supporting Information. For 1 and 3, the peaks are mainly ascribed to the WO2 phase. For 2, the peaks are ascribed to the MoO2 phase.

elements.content: 1–3 are cocrystals of twin CP isomers based on Keggin-POMs and Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties. Keggin-type anions are not easy dissociated from these cocrystals because of the coordinated and electrostatic interactions. Keggin-type anions being inlaid into the ordered isomer CP layers could provide more hopping sites in the layers for proton conduction. Alternate arrangement of twin isomer CP layers in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio could induce water segregation into the pronounced hydrophilic layers. 1–3 have three types of hydrogen-bonding assemblies and two types of proton carriers. Two coordinated hydrogen-bonding ionic/neutral isomer layers and one solvent molecule hydrogen-bonding layer could provide the channels for proton conduction. Being bound to the open coordination sites of Cu2+ ions, coordinated water molecules could act as one type of proton carriers. In addition, the OH groups of H2L ligands could also act as the other type of proton carriers. The proton conductivities of 1–3 should originate from these protons. The robustness of the networks and the hydrophilicity and capacity for inclusion of water molecules are some key factors for good proton conductors. 1–3 are insoluble in water and show good stability and water retention. In a word, 1–3 may be good solid proton-conducting materials and suitable models to study the proton conductivities of cocrystals of twin CP isomers based on Keggin-POMs and Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties.

elements.content: Conductivity measurements are a help to get some insight into the dependence of the proton mobility in these cocrystals with complicated hydrogen-bonding networks on the temperature and RH. As shown in and S9 in the Supporting Information, the ac impedance method was used to evaluate their proton conductivities when the temperature and RH were varied (such as at 25 or 100 °C in the RH range 35–98% and at 98% RH in the temperature range from 25 to 100 °C). In each of 1–3, there are two twin isomers of 2D CPs based on the infinite covalent assembly of Keggin-POMs with the relatively large volume and metal–H2L fragments with strong hydrogen-bond ability. Moreover, through the hydrogen-bonding interactions between H2L oxygen atoms, two twin isomers cocrystalize to give a 3D supramolecular structure with 2D hydrophilic layers. These reveal that 1–3 may maintain the robustness of the hydrogen-bonding networks when they are held at 100 °C with an RH of about 98%. The PXRD data measured at room temperature in Figure S7 in the Supporting Information suggested that the powder samples after the proton-conductive measurement have the same superstructures as those of three cocrystals. In addition, the variable-temperature PXRD data in Figure S8 in the Supporting Information showed that the powder samples even at 100 °C under 35 to about 98% RH have the same superstructures as those of three cocrystals. Thus, the structural descriptions of the hydrogen-bonding networks are valid for the proton conductivities of 1–3 even at 100 °C under 35 to about 98% RH.

elements.content: Proton conductivities of three cocrystals depend closely on the temperature and RH. It can be seen from a–c and S8 in the Supporting Information that their proton conductivities under 98% RH increase gradually with the temperature adding up to 100 °C from 25 °C (1.05 × 10–4 to 2.92 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 1, 2.35 × 10–5 to 2.00 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 2, and 3.71 × 10–5 to 3.71 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 3). The resistances were obtained from the extrapolation to the real axis. c shows that proton conductivities of 1–3 are almost no change with the RH at 25 °C (8.74 × 10–5 to 8.93 × 10–5 S·cm–1 for 1, 2.20 × 10–5 to 2.35 × 10–5 S·cm–1 for 2, and 2.81 × 10–5 to 3.71 × 10–5 S·cm–1 for 3) and increase gradually with the RH at 100 °C (1.28 × 10–4 to 2.24 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 1, 8.72 × 10–5 to 2.00 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 2, and 7.67 × 10–5 to 3.71 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 3). Three cocrystals show better proton conductivities (over 10–4 S·cm–1) at 100 °C than at 25 °C in the RH range of 35–98%. The dissociating processes of protons from coordination water molecules and the OH groups from H2L ligands are temperature-dependent. The high temperature would give a high carrier concentration. The RH and temperature are two of the key factors to improve proton conductivity. The high RH and temperature could accelerate proton transition within their hydrogen-bonding hydrophilic layers.

The RH and temperature are two of the key factors to improve proton conductivity. The high RH and temperature could accelerate proton transition within their hydrogen-bonding hydrophilic layers.

elements.content: The similar structural properties result in their similar proton conductivities. At 25 °C in the RH range of 35–98%, 1 shows higher proton conductivities than 2–3. 1–3 have the same isomer layer spacing based on the shortest distance of P1/Si1···P2/Si2 (18.08 Å for 1, 18.09 Å for 2, and 18.07 Å for 3) and the different mean diameters of Keggin anion on the basis of four coordinated terminal oxygen atoms (10.48 Å for [PW]3–, 10.45 Å for [PMo]3–, and 10.39 Å for [SiW]4–). In 1–3, two isomer layers are arranged alternately. Larger [PW]3– anion in 1 makes two isomer layers contact more closely, which might make 1 show higher proton conductivities than that of 2–3 under the same conditions. The existence of the proton of O47 center makes 3 possess more proton sources than 1–2. 3 shows larger water adsorbing capacity than 1–2 at room temperature and normal pressure (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). These advantages might make 3 give similar proton conductivities as 1 at higher temperature and higher proton conductivities than 2 under the same conditions.

elements.content: It can be seen from d that the ln σT of each of three cocrystals increases almost linearly with temperature range from 25 to 100 °C. The results of the variable-temperature impedance study could give the activation energy of the proton transfer in them. On the basis of an Arrhenius relationship, the corresponding activation energy (E a) of conductivity was estimated to be 0.16 eV for 1, 0.29 eV for 2, and 0.33 eV for 3. By comparison, their E a values are close to those of pure heteropolyacids (0.25–0.4 eV) and lower than those of organic–inorganic complexes based-on Keggin anions and 2,2′-bipyridyl-3,3′-dicarboxylic acid (1.02 or 1.01 eV).

elements.content: Under the same conditions, 1–3 show proton conductivities similar to or lower than some representative Keggin-based compounds with good proton conductivities. Complicated accumulation of three different types of hydrogen-bonding assemblies in the same crystal may be the cause that 1–3 do not reveal one of the best reported conductivity values (over 10–3 S·cm–1). Three different types of hydrogen-bonding assemblies for 1–3 could ensure favorable pathways for proton conduction, in which water-rich conditions are important. The high temperature is more important for obtaining a high carrier concentration, which depends on the dissociating processes of protons from coordination water molecules and the OH groups of the H2L ligand. In addition, 1–3 have low activation energy of conductivity. On the basis of the aforementioned points, the proton conduction for three cocrystals is expected to be the Grotthuss mechanism (the proton transport of additional protons along hydrogen-bonding networks).

elements.content: Moreover, variable temperature impedance spectra for 1–3 are also simulated by the equivalent circuits depicted in Figures S10a–S12a in the Supporting Information. Tables S3–S5 in the Supporting Information show estimated parameters with these equivalent circuits. As shown in Figures S10b–S12b in the Supporting Information, the conductivities at 98% RH in the temperature range from 25 to 100 °C were further estimated by the resistance (R 1) simulated by the equivalent circuits depicted in Figures S10a–S12a. By comparison, the simulated values (1.07 × 10–4 to 2.72 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 1, 8.34 × 10–5 to 4.78 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 2, and 3.01 × 10–5 to 3.11 × 10–4 S·cm–1 for 3) are higher than (for 2) or similar as (for 1–3) the experimental data. In addition, for each of 1–3, the corresponding activation energy (E a) of conductivity based-on the simulated values (0.14 eV for 1, 0.29 eV for 2, and 0.32 eV for 3) is similar as that based on the experimental data (Figures S10c–S12c in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In summary, three cocrystals of in situ twin supramolecular isomers of Keggin-based CPs with Cu­(II)–H2L complex moieties have been for the first time designed and synthesized using conventional solvent method. Cooperativeness of three types of supramolecular isomerism is perfectly embodied in them. Their successful preparation may provide a calculable clue for multi-isomerism-cooperation and cocrystallization of in situ constructed twin supramolecular isomers. They are new types of cocrystals that are part of the intersection of such four research fields as cocrystal, supramolecular isomers, POM chemistry, and metal–organic chemistry. The combination of these four important research fields will exploit new possibilities in seeking for multifunctional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three cocrystals of in situ twin supramolecular isomers of Keggin-based CPs with Cu(II)-H2L complex moieties have been for the first time designed and synthesized using conventional solvent method. Cooperativeness of three types of supramolecular isomerism is perfectly embodied in them. Their successful preparation may provide a calculable clue for multi-isomerism-cooperation and cocrystallization of in situ constructed twin supramolecular isomers. They are new types of cocrystals that are part of the intersection of such four research fields as cocrystal, supramolecular isomers, POM chemistry, and metal-organic chemistry. The combination of these four important research fields will exploit new possibilities in seeking for multifunctional materials.

cln_elements.content:
The copper heteropolyacid salt (CuHPW12O40·nH2O) (90.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CuCl2·6H2O (5.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) were dissolved in a 4 mL water, which was put in the bottom of the test tube. Next, a solution (9 mL) of methanol/acetonitrile/water (1:1:1, v/v/v) was as a buffer layer. Then, a methanol solution (6 mL) of H2L (6.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) and imidazole (3.9 mg, 0.03 mmol) was carefully layered over the buffer layer. Finally, the test tube containing the solution is stoppered and laid aside at room temperature. Light-blue crystals were formed after 4–5 weeks and were collected and dried in air after quickly being washed with water. Yield: 66.6 mg, 74% based on POMs. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C52H86Cu4N8O104P2W24 (7215.78): C, 8.65; H, 1.20; N, 1.55. Found: C, 8.59; H, 1.16; N, 1.48. IR (KBr) ν, cm–1: 804ν­(W–Oc), 889ν­(W–Ob), 980ν­(W–Ot), 1072ν­(P–Oa) (characteristic vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with the Keggin structure); 3417, 3128, 1619, 1399 (vibrations resulting from the H2L ligand).

cln_elements.content: Thermal analyses of three bulk materials in an atmosphere of N2 reveal that the robustness of those networks of cocrystals could retain up to about 300 °C for 1–2 and about 250 °C for 3 (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). In the temperature range of 20–300 °C for 1–2 and 20–250 °C for 3, there is a weight loss of about 3.53% for 1 (4.60% for 2 and 1.90% for 3) corresponding to the loss of all solvent molecules (2.77% for 1, 3.92% for 2, and 2.26% for 3). Above 300 °C for 1–2 and 250 °C for 3, the layer structures of 1–3 begin to decompose because of the loss of coordinated water molecules and H2L ligands, as well as the disrupting of the structural skeletons of the Keggin anions. The weight losses are about 1.22% for 1, 0.93% for 2, and 1.03% for 3 at 100 °C, suggesting that the hydrophilic channels or layers in three complexes could retain some uncoordinated water molecules at 100 °C. The results indicate that three complexes have good water holding in the temperature range of 20–100 °C. The PXRD patterns of the title complexes after heating in an atmosphere of N2 at 700 °C are shown in Figure S5 in the Supporting Information. For 1 and 3, the peaks are mainly ascribed to the WO2 phase. For 2, the peaks are ascribed to the MoO2 phase.

In the temperature range of 20-300 °C for 1-2 and 20-250 °C for 3, there is a weight loss of about 3.53% for 1 (4.60% for 2 and 1.90% for 3) corresponding to the loss of all solvent molecules (2.77% for 1, 3.92% for 2, and 2.26% for 3). Above 300 °C for 1-2 and 250 °C for 3, the layer structures of 1-3 begin to decompose because of the loss of coordinated water molecules and H2L ligands, as well as the disrupting of the structural skeletons of the Keggin anions. The weight losses are about 1.22% for 1, 0.93% for 2, and 1.03% for 3 at 100 °C, suggesting that the hydrophilic channels or layers in three complexes could retain some uncoordinated water molecules at 100 °C. The results indicate that three complexes have good water holding in the temperature range of 20-100 °C. The PXRD patterns of the title complexes after heating in an atmosphere of N2 at 700 °C are shown in Figure S5 in the Supporting Information. For 1 and 3, the peaks are mainly ascribed to the WO2 phase. For 2, the peaks are ascribed to the MoO2 phase.

cln_elements.content: Cocrystal of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers. (a) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu1L-P1W] n n+/[Cu1L-[P1Mo] n n+/[Cu1L-Si1W] n in 1–3. (b) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu2L-P2W] n n–/[Cu2L-P2Mo] n n–/[Cu2L-Si2W] n in 1–3. (c) Cocrystallization of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers through hydrogen bonds in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Cocrystal of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers. (a) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu1L-P1W] n   n+/[Cu1L-[P1Mo] n   n+/[Cu1L-Si1W] n  in 1-3. (b) 2D CP isomer formed by the [Cu2L-P2W] n   n-/[Cu2L-P2Mo] n   n-/[Cu2L-Si2W] n  in 1-3. (c) Cocrystallization of twin ionic/neutral CP isomers through hydrogen bonds in a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio.

cln_elements.content: (a) Quadridecorated ionic Keggin-type cluster, [Cu1L-P1W]+, in the molecular unit of 1 with the labeling atoms at 30% probability thermal ellipsoids. (b) Tetracoordinated mode of [P1W]3– and (c) conformation of the N 1,N 2-H2L in [Cu1L-P1W]+. (d) Two single helix chains with opposite chirality in the hydrogen-bonding double-helix chains. (e) Two types of hydrogen-bonding double-helix chains with opposite chirality formed by the [Cu1L]2+ in 1–3. (f) Hydrogen-bonding assembly formed by the [Cu1L-P1W]+/[Cu1L-P1Mo]+ in 1–2 or the neutral [Cu1L-Si1W] in 3.

(e) Two types of hydrogen-bonding double-helix chains with opposite chirality formed by the [Cu1L]2+ in 1-3.
